section.p: Dear Parents/Guardians,
The Jefferson School District Board of Trustees has determined to continue with distance learning until the end of the school year (June 4), because of the COVID-19 pandemic.

That soft closure began in the Jefferson School District on Wednesday, March 18, and since that time, our educators and staff have worked hard to provide students the best possible remote learning and digital instruction we can offer. We recognize the challenge this has placed on you and your children and we will continue to do our best to help students prosper.

There are certainly many logistical matters to take care of before the end of the school year and we will get specific information to you, through your building principal, as soon as possible regarding end-of-year procedures, including graduation.
These are incredibly unstable and trying times, and we thank you for your ongoing efforts to help us provide an education for your children.
Warmest regards,

Chad Martin
Superintendent

h1.strong: Our Commitment to Health and Safety

section.p: The health and safety of all of our students continues to be our first priority in the wake of the evolving situation around the coronavirus (COVID-19) . We are continuing to monitor the situation very closely.
We are encouraging all of our staff and students to follow these everyday prevention strategies:

ul.li: If you are sick, stay home from school.
Avoid close contact with those who are already sick.
Cover your nose and mouth when coughing or sneezing with a tissue or the crook of your arm.
Wash your hands often with soap and water.
Avoid touching eyes, nose or mouth.

section.p: Visit the Idaho Official Resources page at https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/ for more information on the virus.Below is the link to recommendations from The Center of Disease Control for school closures, regarding COVID-19. Our intention is to continue to closely monitor the situation and work closely with health and medical professionals to make the best decisions possible for our students and our community. CDC Considerations-for-School-Closure We thank you for your patience, support and understanding as we work together to keep our community as safe and healthy as possible.
“Counting Everyone Once, Only Once, and in the Right Place.”

Beginning April 1, 2020, the federal government begins a process that occurs only once every ten years: counting (or attempting to) every person living in the U.S. and collecting demographic data from them.

The 2020 census will be the first “high tech” census. Every household will have the option of responding to the ten questions online – by smartphone, tablet, computer, over the phone, or on paper. Online access in Idaho will occur March 12.

ul.li: The Census Bureau will mail a notice all households encouraging online participation for a completed decennial survey by April 1.
For households that have PO Boxes, a census worker may deliver the survey to the physical address.

The 2020 census will be the first “high tech” census. Every household will have the option of responding to the ten questions online – by smartphone, tablet, computer, over the phone, or on paper. Online access in Idaho will occur March 12. The Census Bureau process anticipates wrapping up its work in late July.

p.strong: The district will post the link for completing the Census when it is opens on March 12.

section.p: The U.S. Constitution mandates that a census of the population, all people living on American soil, be conducted once every ten years (Article 1, Section 2). Census data is used to reapportion Congressional representation among the states and to determine how billions in educational federal funds like Title 1, Migrant and Homeless funds are distributed to states and local school districts every year. Other federal funds that are distributed are for health care, jobs, roads, and businesses. Census data is also used for drawing political boundaries for local, state, and federal elections.
Census Bureau Official Website https://2020census.gov/

div.p: The Board of Trustees adopted Calendar Option 1 for the 2020-2021 school year. This calendar received the most votes from the community, staff and students.
School will begin on Wednesday, September 2 and end on Friday, May 28, 2021. We would like to thank everyone that participated in voting for the school calendar.

We are excited with the progress that is taking place at Cottonwood Elementary, Harwood Elementary and Midway Elementary School. Click on the links below to view the progress of each of the projects.Building Project March 2020

section.p: The Board of Trustees approved new boundary changes at the September 11, board meeting. Due to the new additions to Harwood and Midway Elementary School and the construction of Cottonwood Elementary it was necessary for the district to adjust the school boundaries for the 2020-2021 school year.

Students enrolled in Jefferson, Midway and Roberts Elementary will attend Farnsworth Middle School. Students enrolled in Cottonwood, Harwood and South Fork Elementary will attend Rigby Middle School. Click on the links below to review the new school boundary information:
section.h1: School Bus Drivers & Substitute Teachers Needed

p.img: School Bus Drivers and Substitute Teachers are needed for the school year. Training is provided. To apply for a school bus driver or substitute teacher position go to the Employment Opportunities link on the front page of the district’s website and complete an application. Contact the Transportation Department at (208) 754-8211, or the District Office at (208) 745-6693, if you have any questions.

section.p: Welcome to Jefferson County School District 251. We are located in Rigby, Idaho and our district is rapidly growing. Jefferson County School District is the tenth largest school district in the state of Idaho. The district is made up of 1 preschool center, 6 elementary schools, 1 middle school, 2 high schools, and 1 online high school. Over the past 20 years the district has grown by 53%, with an average of 3.6% annually. The current average enrollment is 6,144 students in grades p-12. The district employs 328 certified staff and 330 non-certified staff.

p.em: “We are a community focused on student learning in order to build, foster informed and productive citizenship, and prepare all youth for college and career success.”
“The mission of Jefferson County School District 251 is to provide each student with a high quality education.”
